Empires & Puzzles Li Kui Review: The Iron Ox of Liangshan

Li Kui brings a rare combination of heavy hitting and defensive utility to Empires & Puzzles. With his ability to deal critical hits on special skills and provide Taunt protection, he is a chaotic force on the battlefield. This review analyzes his viability in the current meta.
Li Kui Review: The Taunting Tornado of Fire
Li Kui: The Iron Ox Who Hits Like a Truck and Takes Hits Like a Tank

Li Kui, also known as the Iron Ox of Water Margin, is a Legendary Fire hero from the Outlaws of Liangshan family. Released in May 2025 as part of the War of Three Kingdoms expansion, he introduces a chaotic but powerful playstyle. He is a Barbarian who breaks the mold by combining the role of a heavy hitter with that of a primary tank or protector. Unlike traditional passive meat shields, Li Kui actively punishes the enemy team while drawing fire away from his allies. He is a hybrid hero in the truest sense, offering high damage output via critical hits and survivability through Taunt and damage reduction.

Li Kui's design is aggressive and rugged, fitting his "Iron Ox" moniker. He sports a wild, spiked hairstyle that has earned him comparisons to Wolverine among the player base. Clad in furs and wielding heavy weaponry, his visual design screams brute force. The artwork does a great job of conveying his dual nature: he looks like someone who is about to hit you very hard, but also someone who can shrug off a blow without flinching. It is a refreshing take on the heavy infantry archetype, leaning more into the wild berserker aesthetic than the disciplined soldier.

Li Kui possesses a stat spread that is well balanced for a frontline fighter. His base stats (approx. 1155 Attack / 1289 Defense / 2237 Health) are competitive, though slightly eclipsed by the absolute latest power creep seen in late 2025 heroes like Adelitza or the Institute family. However, his bulk is substantial enough to let him perform his Taunt duties effectively. Compared to older Red tanks like Black Caesar or even Costume Black Knight, Li Kui holds his own with modern defensive values, ensuring he does not melt under the first wave of tile damage.

Whirlwind Blows is a multi-faceted skill that demands attention. First, it deals 300% damage to the target and 4 random enemies. In a full 5v5 scenario, this effectively functions as a hit-all skill, dealing substantial damage across the board. The twist is the "Chance to deal Critical hits" mechanic. If successful, the damage output spikes by 50%, and in PvP, it reduces the enemy's max health. This makes his offensive potential far higher than typical Taunt heroes.

Simultaneously, he casts Taunt on himself and reduces all received damage by 50% for 4 turns. This is the standard "keep me alive while I protect you" package, but at Average speed, it requires careful timing or mana support to activate before fast snipers take out your key heroes.
Li Kui runs at Average speed. To make him functionally Fast (9 tiles), he needs a 23% mana generation bonus.
No mana node at level 20, but possibly at node 19? Standard Barbarian path does not prioritize mana, but you can choose it.
A Level 29 Magic/Styx/Cyclops troop or a Bard bonus is usually required to shave a tile off his charge time.

His "Righteous Rebellion" passive can grant him +20% mana if hit by a higher HP enemy. This is a massive hidden accelerator. If he takes a hit early, he could charge significantly faster than a standard Average hero.
300% of 1155 Attack = ~3465 value (raw output, not final damage).
If a hit goes critical (based on his crit chance + family bonus), damage increases by 50%.
5 hits x 300% = 1500% total damage distribution. This is sniper-level damage spread across the team, making him one of the hardest-hitting Taunters in the game.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Outlaws of Liangshan family brings a suite of complex interactions that significantly boost Li Kui's viability.

The family bonus provides a 50%/60%/70% chance for Critical Hits for 1/2/3 heroes. For Li Kui alone, a 50% chance to deal 1.5x damage on tiles and specials is huge. This synergizes perfectly with his special skill's intrinsic critical mechanic.
If he scores a critical hit with his special (which is likely given the family bonus), he cleanses the latest ailment from all allies. This adds utility to his brute force.
This is the star of his kit.
If he hits a higher HP enemy, he gains 20% boosted health. Since he hits 5 times, he has multiple chances to trigger this self-heal.
If he is hit by a higher HP enemy, he gains 20% mana. As a Taunt hero, he
be hit. This passive acts as a punish mechanic, helping him cycle his special skill repeatedly.
Situational but useful against Barbarians and specific DOT heroes.

At the start of the battle, Li Kui automatically activates Taunt for a few turns. This is the gold standard for tanking in the modern meta. It protects his team from turn-1 fast snipers and ailment casters, guaranteeing that the rest of your team survives the opening volley.

Released in mid-2025, Li Kui arrived when the meta was shifting towards "do-it-all" heroes. Pure tanks were falling out of favor for tanks that could also kill. Li Kui fit this niche perfectly, offering protection without sacrificing offensive pressure.

Compared to the newest heroes from late 2025 (e.g., the Institute or Titan Hunters), Li Kui's stats are slightly lower but still respectable. His mechanics, however, remain top-tier. Undispellable buffs are becoming rarer, and while his Taunt is dispellable, the sheer amount of damage mitigation and mana gain he possesses keeps him relevant.

Li Kui remains a highly viable hero in upper-diamond raids and wars. His Auto-Taunt Aether Power makes him a premier choice for Rush Attack wars and a solid pick for standard defense teams. He is not just a meat shield; he is a threat that must be answered.
Li Kui currently does not have a costume.

He relies entirely on his base stats and emblem/limit break nodes. Future costumes for the Liangshan family could potentially skyrocket his value if they add stat bonuses or modernize the special skill speed.
As a Barbarian, Li Kui has access to the Bleed talent, which adds minor damage. The real decision is between survival and damage.
Maximizes the value of his Taunt and Damage Reduction. Keeps him alive longer to absorb hits and trigger his "mana on hit" passive.
Lowers the impact of his massive 300% x 5 damage potential.
Leans into his unique identity as a damaging tank. With the critical hit multiplier, every point of Attack is valuable.
He might die slightly faster against heavy blue stacks, risking the loss of his Taunt protection.

path is recommended. However, given his high damage multipliers and critical mechanic, taking Attack nodes where they don't sacrifice major Defense nodes is a smart play. Ensure you grab any Mana nodes available to help his Average speed.
Acts as both a tank (Taunt/Defense) and a flank/wing sweeper (High Damage).
His Aether Power grants immediate team protection.
The passive mana gain when hit allows him to fire more often than his speed suggests.
50% damage reduction plus self-healing via boosted health creates a very durable hero.
Capable of wiping weakened teams alone due to the critical hit mechanic.
His Taunt can be removed by dispellers (e.g., Hippo, countless others), leaving the team exposed.
While "4 random enemies" usually hits everyone in a full team, against fewer enemies, the targeting can be unpredictable.
Without his passive triggering or a Rush environment, he can be too slow against Very Fast teams.
He is an absolute monster here. The speed penalty is removed, and his high impact skill dominates.
His Auto-Taunt forces attackers to bring a dispeller or specific counter, limiting their team building options.
The critical hit chance increases tile damage significantly, and the defense down/protection helps survival against high-level titans.
Great for protecting glass cannons while softening up the enemy defense.
Li Kui thrives in teams that can keep him alive or capitalize on the time he buys.
Li Kui (Tank) flanked by heavy hitters or healers. His Taunt forces tiles into him, generating mana for his passive, while flanks charge up.
Pairing him with a hero like Ludwig or Phorcys. While Taunts don't stack, having a backup protector ensures your team is never exposed.
Pair him with other Liangshan heroes or critical chance boosters to ensure every hit is a crit.
Heroes who dispel buffs before hitting (e.g., Erebus, costumed Sabina) neutralize his primary protective function.
If he is blocked from gaining buffs, he cannot Taunt.
Strong Ice heroes can still punch through his damage reduction if they hit hard enough.

If you are lucky enough to pull Li Kui early, he will carry you through map stages and raids. Focus on leveling him immediately. He can serve as your main tank for a very long time. Do not worry too much about his complex passives; just know that he protects your team and hits hard.

Li Kui is worthy of Limit Break 2 solely for the Auto-Taunt. In the current meta, protecting your team from the initial barrage of Fast/Very Fast specials is critical. Even if his stats age, the utility of start-of-battle Taunt combined with 50% damage reduction keeps him usable in competitive wars. He is a great alternative if you lack the absolute top-tier event tanks.
The community reaction to Li Kui was overwhelmingly positive, with many players appreciating the return of Taunt to the meta.
"Taunt and average speed... sign me up!"
One player noted his deceptive damage: "I don't understand anyone suggesting a buff for this guy. He already can do over 5k damage to a single hero."
He earned the nickname "W3K Wolverine" due to his distinct hairstyle and ferocious nature.
Some users expressed frustration with the "random" targeting when few enemies remain, noting hits could be "wasted" on a dying hero, but generally, he is considered a "real monster."

Li Kui is a chaotic, fun, and incredibly effective hero. He bridges the gap between the stoic defender and the raging berserker. While he may not be the single most broken hero in the history of the game, his kit is packed with so much utility and raw power that he will find a place in your roster for a long time. If you need a hero who can take a punch and punch back twice as hard, the Iron Ox is your man.
Note: The views expressed in this article are those of the author and do not necessarily reflect the views of Small Giant Games.
